name: A Date with History Quiz | Historical Dates | 10 Questions

questions.text: The test for the first atomic bomb occurred in New Mexico on July 16, 1945. The building of the first atomic bomb was a project named after which New York borough?
questions.explanation:
Manhattan.

	The building of the first atomic bomb was known as the Manhattan Project by scientists in America because ten of its key sites were in Manhattan.  The test for the first atomic bomb occurred in New Mexico on July 16, 1945. No one knew just what the nuclear bomb was going to do and a lie had to be made up to explain the large hole made by the detonation of the bomb. After a successful detonation, President Truman was told that the atomic bomb had worked perfectly.

questions.text: The stock market crash of October 29, 1929 is commonly known as what day?
questions.explanation:
Black Tuesday.

	Because of the stock market crash of 1929, the banking system was a mess when President Roosevelt became president in 1933. In order to fix the damage as best he could, President Roosevelt closed all the banks for three days. Before re-opening, each bank was given strict guidelines on citizens withdrawing money from the banks. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was started because of the stock market crash. With the FDIC, banks could go out of business, but depositors would still get their money through the government.

questions.text: On January 1, 1863, President Lincoln signed an executive order during the American Civil War that would free slaves in ten states. What did this order become known as?
questions.explanation:
Emancipation Proclamation.

	The Emancipation Proclamation was signed by President Lincoln in the third year of the American Civil War.  This executive order was put into effect after Lincoln threatened the South with it in August of 1862. The Emancipation Proclamation nominally freed the slaves in the Confederate states, but for the most part, could not be put into effect immediately. It also give freed slaves the right to join the military and by war's end over 200,000 former slaves had served in the American Civil War. However, it was the 13th Amendment rather than the Emancipation Proclamation that ended slavery.

questions.text: Apollo 11 was the first U.S. manned lunar module to land on the moon. In July of what year was regularly scheduled programming cut into to air this magnificent feat?
questions.explanation:
1969.

	On the moon, a crew of Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin were the first and second men to walk on the moon while Michael Collins was the command module pilot and had to stay in the space shuttle to pilot it. The crew of Apollo 11 left an American flag, a patch honoring the crew of Apollo 1, and a plaque that stated "Here men from the planet Earth first set foot upon the moon. July 1969 A.D. We came in peace for all mankind."

questions.text: On May 17, 1954 what case brought an end to segregation in schools?
questions.explanation:
Brown vs. Board of Education

	Brown vs. Board of Education was brought about when father Oliver Brown thought his child's 14th amendment rights to equality were being infringed upon by her not attending school closer to where she lives because it wasn't a black school. Oliver Brown's daughter had to travel miles out of the way to attend her all black school when Sumner Elementary, a white school, was a mile from the Brown house.When thirteen other families along with the Browns took their children to enroll them in Sumner Elementary they were turned away. This action gave the families what they needed to take the Kansas Board of Education to court.Because Oliver Brown was the only male parent in the group of thirteen parents, his name was put on the case against the BOE. When the case favored for segregating students, an appeal was taken to the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court agreed with Oliver Brown and the other families on May 17, 1954 and segregation in schools was suspended based on the 14th amendment.

questions.text: In April 25, 1898, the _______-American war began when America interfered with the Cuban war of Independence. With whom did America go to war?
questions.explanation:
Spanish.

	The United States declared war on Spain on April 25, 1898 after the USS Maine was destroyed in Havana harbor. The Treaty of Paris ended the Spanish-American war and left Spain with no control over Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Philippines. With Spain giving up control of these countries, the United States now had power in the Pacific and the Caribbean.

questions.text: On June 17, 1972, five men were arrested at a hotel in Washington trying to gain information on President Nixon's opponents at the office of the Democratic National Committee. The scandal became named for what famous hotel in Washington D.C.?
questions.explanation:
Watergate.

	The Watergate hotel in Washington D.C. was the home of the office for the Democratic National Committee. On the night of June 17, 1972, five men were arrested for trying to break into DNC headquarters. There involvement was traced back to a Nixon cover-up and two years later President Richard Nixon resigned to avoid impeachment.

questions.text: What war did the U.S. enter on 6 April 1917?
questions.explanation:
World War I.

	Early in 1917 Germany resumed unresricted submarine warfare, thus violating undertakings it had made to the U.S. At the same time Germany was trying to persuade Mexico to go to war against the U.S. On 2 April 1917 President Wilson took the matter to Congress and four days later declared war on Germany. The United States declared on Austria-Hungary later - on 7 December 1917.

questions.text: Gold was discovered in California on January 24, 1848. What was the name of the mill where it was discovered?
questions.explanation:
Sutter's Mill.

	Sutter's Mill was co-owned by John Sutter and James Marshall. The mill was close to the South Fork American River where James Marshall found flakes of gold on January 24, 1848. Those few flakes of gold changed the landscape of California forever. The Smithsonian now holds a flake of gold that John Marshall discovered on that January day.

questions.text: A coalition of thirty-four nations went to war (codenamed Operation Desert Storm) with Iraq in January of what year?
questions.explanation:
1991.

	The U.N. authorized a coalition force of thirty-six nations to head to the Middle East to defend Kuwait against an Iraqi invasion. The first images broadcast of Operation Desert Storm were of the bombing of Baghdad.
